fields.name: Bock
fields.history: Originating in Germany, Bocks are known for their robust flavors.

fields.name: Doppelbock
fields.history: Originally brewed by monks for sustenance during Lent.

fields.name: Eisbock
fields.description: A Bock beer that's been frozen
fields.history: Created accidentally when a Bock beer froze, concentrating its flavors.

fields.name: Maibock
fields.history: Traditionally brewed in May for spring celebrations.

fields.name: Weizenbock
fields.history: A marriage of Bock and wheat beer styles.

fields.name: Altbier
fields.history: Hailing from Düsseldorf, Germany, known for its unique fermentation.

fields.name: American Brown Ale
fields.history: An American twist on the traditional English Brown Ale.

fields.name: Belgian Dark Ale
fields.history: Belgian craftsmanship meets dark, flavorful malts.

fields.name: English Brown Ale
fields.history: A staple of British pubs, known for its drinkability.

fields.name: English Dark Mild Ale
fields.history: A low-alcohol, sessionable ale with a rich malt character.

fields.name: Dubbel
fields.history: Originally brewed by Trappist monks, known for its complexity and dark fruit notes.

fields.name: Roggenbier
fields.history: A rare style, brewed with rye malt, giving it a unique spiciness.

fields.name: Scottish Ale
fields.history: Hailing from Scotland, known for its malty sweetness and low bitterness.

fields.name: Winter Warmer
fields.history: Typically brewed during the winter months with spices and higher alcohol content.

fields.name: American Amber / Red Lager
fields.history: An American take on the Vienna Lager, known for its balance between malt and hops.

fields.name: Czech Amber Lager
fields.history: A Czech classic with a malt-forward profile and moderate bitterness.

fields.name: Czech Dark Lager
fields.history: A Czech specialty with dark malts and a clean, crisp finish.

fields.name: European Dark Lager
fields.history: A lager style popular in Europe, offering a balanced malt profile.

fields.name: Märzen
fields.history: Originally brewed in March (März in German), known for its amber color and maltiness.

fields.name: Munich Dunkel
fields.history: A Munich classic, characterized by its malt-forward, dark, and smooth nature.

fields.name: Rauchbier
fields.history: Brewed with smoked malt, known for its distinctive smoky aroma and flavor.

fields.name: Schwarzbier
fields.history: Often called "Black Pilsner," it's a dark lager with a smooth and roasty character.

fields.name: Vienna Lager
fields.history: Originating in Vienna, it's known for its moderate bitterness and toasty maltiness.

fields.name: Bière de Champagne / Bière Brut
fields.history: Inspired by Champagne, it undergoes a second fermentation for a bubbly, dry finish.

fields.name: Braggot
fields.history: Combines malt and honey, an ancient style enjoying a resurgence in craft brewing.

fields.name: California Common / Steam Beer
fields.history: Originally from California, known for its lager yeast at ale fermentation temperatures.

fields.name: Cream Ale
fields.history: A hybrid style with ale yeast and lagering, offering a clean and crisp profile.

fields.name: American IPA
fields.history: A modern classic known for its bold hop flavors and aromas.

fields.name: Belgian IPA
fields.history: Combines Belgian yeast character with American hop bitterness.

fields.name: Black IPA
fields.history: Also known as Cascadian Dark Ale, it blends dark malts with IPA hoppiness.

fields.name: Brut IPA
fields.history: A recent innovation characterized by its bone-dry finish and high carbonation.

fields.name: English IPA
fields.history: A traditional British take on the IPA, with a more restrained hop character.

fields.name: Imperial IPA
fields.history: Known for its high alcohol content and bold hop flavors, a favorite of hopheads.

fields.name: Milkshake IPA
fields.history: Contains lactose for a creamy mouthfeel and often includes fruit additions.

fields.name: New England IPA
fields.history: A newer style known for its cloudiness and juicy, tropical fruit flavors.

fields.name: American Amber / Red Ale
fields.history: An American classic, offering a balance of malt sweetness and hop bitterness.

fields.name: American Blonde Ale
fields.history: A crowd-pleaser with a clean and mild flavor profile.

fields.name: American Pale Ale
fields.history: An iconic American style known for its hop character and balance.

fields.name: Belgian Blonde Ale
fields.history: Brewed in Belgium, it combines fruity yeast esters with a pale malt backbone.

fields.name: Belgian Pale Ale
fields.history: Known for its moderate alcohol content and Belgian yeast character.

fields.name: Bière de Garde
fields.history: Originating in France, it's often aged and exhibits a range of malt flavors.

fields.name: English Bitter
fields.history: A traditional British pub beer known for its easy-drinking nature.

fields.name: English Pale Ale
fields.history: Known for its moderate hop bitterness and malt-forward character.

fields.name: English Pale Mild Ale
fields.history: A mild beer with a focus on maltiness, perfect for extended drinking sessions.

fields.name: Extra Special / Strong Bitter (ESB)
fields.history: A traditional British pub ale, known for its balanced bitterness and malt sweetness.

fields.name: Grisette
fields.description: A light and rustic Belgian ale
fields.history: Originally brewed for miners in Belgium, it's a refreshing and low-alcohol beer.

fields.name: Irish Red Ale
fields.history: A classic Irish style, known for its reddish hue and balanced malt character.

fields.name: Kölsch
fields.description: A clean and crisp German ale
fields.history: Brewed in Cologne, Germany, it's an ale that's lagered for a clean, refreshing profile.

fields.name: Saison
fields.description: A farmhouse ale with a twist
fields.history: Originally brewed in Belgian farmhouses, it's now made with various flavor additions.

fields.name: American Adjunct Lager
fields.history: Often includes corn or rice adjuncts for a clean and approachable taste.

fields.name: American Lager
fields.history: An iconic American beer style, known for its light and easy-drinking nature.

fields.name: Bohemian / Czech Pilsner
fields.history: A Czech classic with a balanced hop bitterness and golden color.

fields.name: Czech Pale Lager
fields.history: A lighter version of the Czech Pilsner, known for its drinkability.

fields.name: European / Dortmunder Export Lager
fields.history: Originally from Dortmund, Germany, it's a well-balanced, export-style lager.

fields.name: European Pale Lager
fields.history: A lager style popular in Europe, known for its clean and easy-drinking nature.

fields.name: European Strong Lager
fields.history: Strong lagers vary in flavor, but they tend to be maltier and higher in alcohol content.

fields.name: Festbier / Wiesnbier
fields.history: Brewed for Oktoberfest celebrations in Germany, it's known for its drinkability.

fields.name: German Pilsner
fields.history: A staple in Germany, known for its clean taste and noble hop bitterness.

fields.name: Helles
fields.history: A Munich classic, offering a malt-forward profile and a light, golden appearance.

fields.name: Imperial Pilsner
fields.history: A higher-alcohol version of the Pilsner style with more pronounced hop bitterness.

fields.name: India Pale Lager (IPL)
fields.history: Combines the clean profile of a lager with the hoppy attributes of an IPA.

fields.name: Kellerbier / Zwickelbier
fields.history: Typically served straight from the fermentation tank, it's known for its freshness.

fields.name: Light Lager
fields.history: Designed for a lower calorie intake while maintaining a light, refreshing taste.

fields.name: Malt Liquor
fields.history: Known for its higher alcohol content and sweet, grainy flavors.

fields.name: American Porter
fields.history: A classic American style with dark malt flavors and a hint of bitterness.

fields.name: Baltic Porter
fields.history: Originally brewed in the Baltic region, it's a strong, dark lager with complex flavors.

fields.name: English Porter
fields.history: Known for its chocolate and caramel notes, it's a favorite in British pubs.

fields.name: Imperial Porter
fields.history: A higher-alcohol version of the porter style, often with bold coffee and chocolate notes.

fields.name: Robust Porter
fields.history: Known for its rich, roasted malt flavors, it's a robust and flavorful dark ale.

fields.name: Smoked Porter
fields.history: Brewed with smoked malt, it offers a unique smokiness and complexity.

fields.name: Chile Beer
fields.history: Often made with chili peppers, providing heat and unique flavors to the beer.

fields.name: Fruit and Field Beer
fields.history: Includes various fruits or field ingredients to create a fruity and refreshing profile.

fields.name: Gruit / Ancient Herbed Ale
fields.history: Brewed with a mixture of herbs and spices instead of hops, a traditional style.

fields.name: Happoshu
fields.history: Contains less malt than regular beer to reduce taxes, popular in Japan.

fields.name: Herb and Spice Beer
fields.history: Features a variety of herbs and spices for unique and complex flavors.

fields.name: Japanese Rice Lager
fields.history: Made with rice adjuncts, resulting in a light and clean taste, popular in Japan.

fields.name: Kvass
fields.history: Traditionally made from stale bread, offering a unique bready flavor.

fields.name: Low-Alcohol Beer
fields.history: Designed for those seeking a beer with minimal alcohol content.

fields.name: Pumpkin Beer
fields.history: Typically brewed with pumpkin and spices like cinnamon and nutmeg.

fields.name: Rye Beer
fields.history: Features rye malt alongside barley for a distinctive spicy character.

fields.name: Sahti
fields.history: Brewed with juniper branches and berries, it's a historic Finnish beer style.

fields.name: Smoked Beer
fields.history: Uses malt that has been dried over an open flame or smoked wood, offering smoky flavors.

fields.name: American Imperial Stout
fields.history: Known for its bold flavors of roasted malt, chocolate, and coffee, often high in alcohol.

fields.name: American Stout
fields.history: A hop-forward stout with a robust roastiness, often with American hop varieties.

fields.name: English Stout
fields.history: Known for its dry and roasty character, with flavors of coffee and dark chocolate.

fields.name: Foreign / Export Stout
fields.history: Originally brewed for export, it's characterized by its bold roastiness and bitterness.

fields.name: Irish Dry Stout
fields.history: Known for its dry finish and lower alcohol content, a staple in Irish pubs.

fields.name: Oatmeal Stout
fields.history: Contains oats for a silky texture and flavors of chocolate and coffee.

fields.name: Russian Imperial Stout
fields.history: Originally brewed for the Russian court, it's a high-alcohol stout with bold flavors.

fields.name: Sweet / Milk Stout
fields.history: Contains lactose for a sweet and creamy mouthfeel, often with notes of chocolate.

fields.name: American Barleywine
fields.history: A high-alcohol ale with a rich malt backbone and pronounced hop bitterness.

fields.name: American Strong Ale
fields.history: Known for its complexity, it combines strong malt character with hoppy notes.

fields.name: Belgian Dark Strong Ale
fields.history: Often brewed by Belgian Trappist monasteries, it's a complex and strong ale.

fields.name: Belgian Pale Strong Ale
fields.history: A Belgian style that combines fruity yeast esters with a sturdy malt backbone.

fields.name: English Barleywine
fields.description: A rich and malty British ale
fields.history: Known for its malt sweetness and high alcohol content, often aged like wine.

fields.name: English Strong Ale
fields.history: A traditional British strong ale with a balance of malt and hop character.

fields.name: Imperial Red Ale
fields.history: Combines the hoppy nature of an IPA with the maltiness of a red ale, often high in alcohol.

fields.name: Old Ale
fields.description: A rich and aged British ale
fields.history: Typically aged for extended periods, it's known for its complex and aged flavors.

fields.name: Quadrupel (Quad)
fields.history: A Belgian-style ale with strong malt character and a variety of fruity notes.

fields.name: Scotch Ale / Wee Heavy
fields.description: A strong and malty Scottish ale
fields.history: Hailing from Scotland, it's known for its rich, malty, and caramelized flavors.

fields.name: Tripel
fields.description: A strong and fruity Belgian ale
fields.history: Typically brewed by Trappist monasteries, it's a strong and complex Belgian ale.

fields.name: Wheatwine
fields.history: A high-alcohol beer made with a significant proportion of wheat in the grain bill.

fields.name: American Dark Wheat Beer
fields.history: Combines dark malts with wheat for a unique blend of roasty and wheaty flavors.

fields.name: American Pale Wheat Beer
fields.history: Known for its combination of wheat crispness and hoppy character.

fields.name: Dunkelweizen
fields.description: A dark and wheaty German ale
fields.history: A traditional German style, known for its dark wheaty malt character and banana notes.

fields.name: Grodziskie
fields.description: A light and smoky Polish ale
fields.history: A historic Polish beer style, characterized by its light body and smoky flavor.

fields.name: Hefeweizen
fields.history: Known for its yeast-derived flavors of banana and clove, a beloved German style.

fields.name: Kristallweizen
fields.description: A clear and filtered wheat ale
fields.history: A filtered version of Hefeweizen, offering a clear appearance and a clean taste.

fields.name: Witbier
fields.history: Brewed with orange peel and coriander, it's a refreshing and citrusy Belgian style.

fields.name: Berliner Weisse
fields.history: Known for its tartness and often served with flavored syrups in Berlin, Germany.

fields.name: Brett Beer
fields.history: Fermented with Brettanomyces yeast, offering unique funkiness and complexity.

fields.name: Faro
fields.description: A sweet and sour Belgian ale
fields.history: Typically made by blending young and old lambics, resulting in a sweet-tart profile.

fields.name: Flanders Oud Bruin
fields.description: A tart and malty Belgian ale
fields.history: Known for its deep brown color and complex blend of tartness and maltiness.

fields.name: Flanders Red Ale
fields.description: A sour and fruity Belgian ale
fields.history: A Belgian ale aged in oak barrels, offering a tart and fruity character.

fields.name: Fruit Lambic
fields.description: A fruity and wild Belgian ale
fields.history: Made with real fruit, it's known for its fruity flavors and spontaneous fermentation.

fields.name: Fruited Kettle Sour
fields.description: A sour ale with added fruit
fields.history: Typically soured in the kettle and then fruited for a fruity and sour combination.

fields.name: Gose
fields.description: A sour and salty German ale
fields.history: Brewed with coriander and salt, it's a refreshing and slightly salty sour ale.

fields.name: Gueuze
fields.description: A complex and blended Belgian ale
fields.history: A blend of young and old lambics, offering a complex and effervescent experience.

fields.name: Lambic
fields.history: Spontaneously fermented with wild yeast, it's a base for various sour beer styles.

fields.name: Wild Ale
fields.history: Made with wild yeast and bacteria, offering a wide range of flavors and aromas.
